Award.AwardTitle: Light-Induced Magnetic Switching as a Trigger for Phase Transitions in Molecular Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division is funding a collaborative research team led by Professors Mykhailo Shatruk and Nar S. Dalal of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Florida State University to investigate photoresponsive molecules that can translate the action of heat, pressure, or light irradiation into substantial changes into changes in the magnetic and structural properties of materials. The successful implementation of this design principle could potentially lead to new ferroelectrics and conductors that could be actuated by the action of light. Leveraging the expertise of the Shatruk and Dalal groups in the synthesis and characterization of magnetic and photomagnetic materials, ferroelectric materials, and organic conductors, the team aims to create novel multifunctional materials that can be employed in electronic devices or light-activated switches. The project will actively involve graduate and undergraduate students in laboratory research, including students from groups underrepresented in physical sciences. The research team plans to continue their Undergraduate Summer Schools on Magnetism, first organized in Summers of 2012 and 2014, with the next school scheduled for Summer 2016.

This project targets the synthesis and characterization of photoresponsive molecules capable of translating temperature-, pressure-, or light-induced changes in the magnetic state of the system into substantial structural changes, which consequently would trigger another type of phase transition in the material. The Shatruk/Dalal team will explore approaches to couple the photoinduced magnetic bistability at the molecular level to long-range metal-insulator transitions and ferroic orderings (magnetic or electric) in molecule-based materials. In particular, the team will study Fe(II) complexes with spin crossover (SCO) behavior, which stems from the temperature or light-induced transition between diamagnetic low-spin (LS) and paramagnetic high-spin (HS) states of the Fe(II) ion. The photoinduced LS to HS transitions will be invoked in order to achieve properties such as ferroelectricity and conductivity via photoexcitation. Materials in which SCO coexists with conductivity will provide a platform to test the effects of concerted atomic displacements associated with SCO on the conductivity of the organic substructure, with the potential to achieve photoinduced superconductivity via chemical compression. Another thrust aims to explore photoinduced magnetic switching, akin to SCO, in metal-free organic systems, where the change in the magnetic state is due to interconversions between paramagnetic radicals and diamagnetic dimers of radicals. The study of such metal-free systems could open up a new area in the molecular magnetism field that would parallel the studies currently performed on transition metal complexes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This project has focused on investigation of magnetic bistability in organic radicals and transition metal complexes. We were especially interested in spin-state transitions that could be impacted by irradiation or applied pressure.

Among organic systems, a remarkable paramagnet-diamagnet phase transition was observed in an N-adamantane-derived N-oxyl radical. The paramagnetic radicals dimerize upon cooling, while the diamagnetic dimers cleave upon heating, with the huge 40 K difference (hysteresis) between the two events. The hysteresis was also extremely sensitive to minor change in applied pressure. The structural analysis using advanced synchrotron- and neutron-scattering techniques have revealed that the transition proceeds from the high-temperature plastic (rotationally disordered) crystal to the low-temperature ordered crystalline phase, which explains the large hysteresis loop and offers a unique mechanism for generating magnetic bistability in organic materials.

We have synthesized several hybrid materials, in which transition metal spin-crossover complexes are co-crystallized with stacks organic radicals. These inorganic-organic hybrids exhibits both temperature- and light-driven spin-state switching and high electrical conductivity. Importantly, we have devised a reproducible and effective method for obtaining sufficiently large crystals of such materials, which thus allow structural characterization in both the high-spin and low-spin states, important for the understanding of synergy between the magnetic-state conversion and conducting properties. In one case, we observed an abrupt spin transition, which is, to the best of our knowledge, the first case of such behavior among spin-crossover conductors.

A new family of spin-crossover complexes based on {N4S2} coordination around the Fe(II) ion has been developed. Such coordination environment is very rare for spin-crossover compounds, with only one example being reported prior to our work. We have applied two different S-containing ligand to the design of such complexes, which afforded the possibility to tune the spin-crossover temperature in a wide range. Two of these complexes showed light-induced spin-state transition.

Our fundamental work on the spin-crossover complexes has led to establishment of a remarkably simple rule for predicting spin state of complexes, in which the Fe(II) ion is surrounded by three identical diimine-type ligands. We showed that the most important parameter for defining the spin state, and thus the possibility of spin crossover, is the distance between the N atoms in a free ligand. The simpicity of this rule is astonishing but well-justified by both common-sense arguments and higher-level theoretical analysis. We and other groups have already used this rule successfully for the design of new spin-crossover complexes and modification of their properties.

Broader Impacts. The project has provided training to 1 postdoctoral researcher (female), 6 graduate students (3 females; 4 students have defended PhD dissertations), and 9 undergraduate students (5 females, 3 minority students, and 1 REU student). In addition to the research training in the lab, the students also participated in scientific meetings and workshops to gain new skills and begin building their professional networks.

The project led to a number of new collaborations with research groups at Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, University of Geneva, University of Southern Denmark, Indian Institute of Technology in Kharagpur, University of Alabama at Huntsville, and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. These collaborations also offered new research experiences to student participants.
